keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to at least 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting a higher figure of 48.

The flooding was caused by heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which affected five Mexican states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosí.
Specific fatalities include 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people remain missing, and around 320,000 people have experienced power outages, with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
The government has mobilized the military to conduct rescue operations and distribute aid, with President Claudia Sheinbaum stating that 'we will not leave anyone without support.'
Photos from military operations show evacuations using life rafts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating waist-high water.
Mexico has experienced unusually heavy rainfall this year, with Mexico City recording its rainiest June in over two decades.
The remnants of Tropical Rainstorm Raymond are expected to impact southern Baja California on Sunday.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have caused widespread flooding and landslides across central and southeastern Mexico, affecting five states including Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosí. The death toll has risen to at least 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting 48 fatalities and dozens still missing. Around 320,000 people face power outages, and 16,000 homes have been damaged. The government has mobilized the military for rescue operations and aid distribution, with President Claudia Sheinbaum affirming that no one will be left without support. The event underscores Mexico’s heightened vulnerability to extreme weather, especially in light of record rainfall in Mexico City and other regions this year.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
